comment: I find this strangely complex, especially on the nose. N: pine needles, mint, some citrus. P: grain, more mint and other herbs F: clean and dry

It's LDI's 95% rye recipe under yet another label. But LDI's 95% rye is good stuff--minty, menthol, pine, bubblegum, a hint of gin-y-ness--and so is this. Identical to Bulleit Rye, so if you like this flavour, buy whichever of the two is cheaper.

Huge fan of this brand, giving them an extra star just for that. Tastes like someone left a stick of gum in the whiskey overnight, which is a compliment. Very smooth going down and I will buy anything George Dickel has to offer.
Always overlooked. Excellent whiskey for the price.

Not too sweet.  

En joyed this at Aimee's party.
rye spice, cantaloupe, cinnimonn, winter mint, quick burn gives way to a smooth finish. has the tell tale juicy fruit rye finish. very good whisky, especially at $16 a bottle. [83]

Very mild in flavor when I compare it to other ryes I've had before. I still get the vanilla, spice, herbs and sweet but I feel as if the volume is muted. Similar to the way Glenlivet 12 tastes in comparison to its Macallan counterpart. Overall still a great rye suitable for drinking neat but won't be insulted by being mixed in a Manhattan or an old fashioned.
Tends to be a bit overpowering, as in too many flavors,  for my taste buds. It's good, but there are other ryes i'd rather drink.
Mint & pickle (?!) combine to make a unique enjoyable dram.
Full of spice and a variety of flavor.  Very easy drinker

So..I know that bulleit uses the same stock but man, the two couldn't be more different in my opinion. Dickel is much less sweet, great rye spice. Doesn't linger as long as Bulleit but just tastes more like a real whiskey to me. I just bought this for 20 dollars ...20! Not on sale either. It feels like robbery being this good for that price. I'm ruined.

If you don't know Fickle,  you know Jack. 
I know dickle
Mild rye without any strong distinction. Definitely taste the spearmint and herb flavors.  Not my favorite, but would drink again.
Tastiest rye I've had in this price range. The higher proof adds to the texture as well. Recommended

Very light on the nose with notes of caramel, pear, and light citrus notes.

Finishes with oaky, spicy, citrus notes. Very smooth rye. Buy it, you'll love it, and your wallet will love it too.
Not overly sweet, nice finish. I've had smoother...
Pretty sure I had this one at midnight mile.
The best 20 dollar bottle around.  Cant beat it.
A lot more going on in this than I expected. Easily the champion of its price range.
Rhymes with pickle and tastes like dill. Go figure

6/30/16 $26.99

I probably should have more faith in one of my local-ish producers, but I was really impressed with this rye expression from Dickel. This one bottle will make me take a detour next time I head south with an extra hour or two.

Ok yes u all know I love me some rye. And I love the spicy and dry finish of this dram. There is just a hint of sweet and great anise hiding under the dry sand that is the base of this drink.  I love it.  But hold the phone. Wow is it hot!  I have tried ice water and blowing on it and the heat is up front in the middle and on the back side.  Now I am a manly man and I can take it but whoa nelly if the fire was tamed a tad bit this would be a 5 star.  As it is

Unique nose of vanilla, spearmint, oak, clove and dried fruit. The palate is a great balance of mouthfeels with good weight yet delicate texture. Herbaceous notes flood the palate leading way to toasty character and smoke creeps in upon swallow. The finish is lengthy, especially for the price and resolves with soft, fruity notes of raisin and toasted almond.
The pickle is strong in this one.

Peppermint, dill, grassy marijuana, spicy aroma.  Spicy, peppermint, dill over the tongue.  Smooth and tasty.  Worthy of the George Dickle brand.

Revisit to GD Rye.  The aroma it heaven.  This is beauty in the bottle.  Gorgeous aroma and taste.  Sugar maple filtering makes this a wonderful rye.  Maybe I'm bias to  my home state brand, but this is wonderful for the rye drinker.

Have been wanting to give this one a try, but my local ABC doesn't carry it. Decided to pick up a bottle while travelling the other day. It has been a long time since I've had Bulleit (LDI/MGP's 95% Rye) so I can't compare GD Rye to it, but I can compare it to a more recent purchase, James E.Pepper (Also an LDI/MGP 95% Rye). They are very similar. Both have a Rye heavy nose with a heavy dose of dill and an almost shellac or varnish note. On the palate this one is missing the vanilla sweetness on entry that the JEP has. It's there, just not as pronounced. I don't know if that is a by product of the longer aging, the charcoal filtering, or the lower proof. The dill is there, as well as the peppery spice. A minty aftertaste lingers after a short, sharp finish. While I liked the JEP a little better, this one is around $10 cheaper and worked just as well in my Old Fashioned. Not my favorite rye, but still a solid choice.
I'm just starting to explore the world of rye. I like this, but not as much as Dickel's other whiskies.
Best non-blended (non High West) MGP rye I've had, better than Bulleit and Russell's Reserve Ryes.

Excellent value! This site's description and tasting notes are on the mark, however, there is a stoney woodsy character it doesn't mention that really adds to the body and quality of this (very inexpensive) fine rye!

Also fantastic in a classic Old-Fashioned with a small batch aromatic bitters like Dashfire Brandy Old-fashioned bitters!
6/11/2017...picked up at Missies because priced at $20/750ml.
spice and mint...great in an old fashion or mint julep
not good. not full bodied or tasty but really spicy
Spicy, good for both mixer and neat
35-40$ charcoal mellowed slightly more smooth than templeton rye for my palate
One of the first Ryes that really showcased dill for me. Nose was faint, and the finish a bit hot. Not bad for its price range. I imagine it would hold up in cocktails well, but I have not tried.

I first tried this whiskey last summer and really liked it.  I've been wanting to get some more to give it a proper tasting and I finally did.  It's even better than I remember.

In the glass it's a nice medium amber honey color.  It coats the glass well and produces nice thick, long legs.

First impression on the nose is spice, oak, and alcohol.  Letting it sit for a while brings out a grassy/floral tone with vanilla and maybe some lemon notes.  Even more time in the glass reveals hints of caramel.  The longer it stayed in the glass, the more sweetness came out in both the nose and the palate.

In the mouth this dram has a big, bright rye spice character that was immediately noticeable.  Like the nose, the palate benefits from time in the glass, with vanilla, cinnamon, and hints of caramel coming out after some time.  It has a fairly thick mouthfeel.  The finish is warm, fairly long, sweet and peppery.

This is a very drinkable rye whiskey that is enjoyable any way you like: on the rocks, neat, or in cocktails.  Add in it's $20 price tag and you have an excellent value as well.  Solid 4.0/80.
Taste is way above its price point.👍🏼👍🏼
Sweet, citrus VERY NICE for the price
Dill. Floral. The Glenlivet 12 of ryes... grassy and inexpensive. Not overly complex, but for under $30, I ain't complainin'.

Simply put: it’s worth much more than its cost. 

It makes a wonderful Old Fashioned and holds its own on the rocks. 

For $26, it’s a must-try.
great for old fashioned's and cocktails. wish it was a higher proof
Just finished this bottle, great rye in my opinion, love the spicy herbal flavours! Might buy a new bottle, only 30 Canadian $ here in Quebec.
high 3...very unique flavor. had in Vegas 2.2018
Excellent sipping neat. Drank at Stockpot.
A favorite sipper.  Delicate, but not boring.  Very little alcohol heat. If you want to know what 'herbal' tastes like..try this.  Almost gin-like, minus the juniper

One of the many MGP sourced ryes, only Dickel doesn't try to hide it. What makes this one unique is that it is chilled and filtered through charcoal made of sugar maple wood. There is dill on the nose, smells like a fresh loaf of bread. Spice, pepper and sweet on the palate, spicy finish. Save you money on all the high priced "fad" ryes out there. At under $ 25.00 this is a real keeper.
Easy drinking rye, nice spice notes and quite sweet
Oade's Big 10, East Lansing, 2016; invoked throughout Jim Harrison's "The English Major"
This is a nice solid Rye. My only compliant is I wish it was higher proof. 3.5 stars

A solid daily drinker rye. As many note, it is herbal and even grassy. I call it the camomile tea of whiskey. No strong flavors, but there's no lack of flavor. A gentle alcohol astrigency on the nose, gentle because it is tempered by aloe, after which I pick up a light layer of sweet raw almond and spice. The palate doesn't drag its feet---it gives you what its got in quick order, a lovely herbal bouquet. That compact taste profile gives it a reliable simplicity that's hard to dislike. Light radish and bay leaf with a sprinkle of pepper hovers above the soft spice finish, which infuses itself into a sugar cookie as it fades. You set your head back, and realize you're quite pleased.
Very strong spicy flavor.  More spicy than most ryes even, but it grows on you.  Good neat.
My standard. Nice spiciness and with some vanilla notes in the finish
Tasted the clove and peppery notes.  Did not like it as much neat.
Smooth, enjoyable taste of Christmas spice. There is an initial dill aroma that is not off-putting and gives way to an excellent sipper.

Nose- Cinnamon and black pepper
Body- This is mostly a mild yet dry spice. The spice is more earthy than sweet. 
Finish- Fairly crisp and clean.

Not a remarkable whiskey but not bad either. I don’t get that unpleasant pickle brine.
Nice strong rye and oak flavor. Somewhat sweet and mellow. Not that dry and not too much alcohol burn.
Had tiny samples of makers mark, crown royal, and this at an airport lounge. This is a Solid dram. Has flavors of apples, cinnamon, and Barrel spices on the palate.
Great drink for under $30. This will be a go to for me. I’m not all fancy with descriptions but this was a nice smooth tasting rye (oxymoron I know).

Admittedly, my palate may have been off (bought this bottle to place in a small barrel I have and was tasting the navy strength gin that I had resting in the barrel before I had tasted this) but it wasn't as spicy as I was expecting. Instead it was sweet, but not in an unpleasant way. Almost like a sweet herbal tea. Kinda earthy, mellow, and very sippable.  Not the greatest rye I've ever had but still an excellent value for the price.

I'm no expert on Rye, but I thought this was pretty darn good. have not had more than a few. Great spice flavor - like a fruit cake. Clove! Good, full, and rich with a nice fruity taste to boot. I've also had Sazerek and Bulleit Rye. I liked this better. Sorry, Distiller.com. Don't agree on this one I guess.

My least favorite of the Dickels.  It’s got a dill candy quality to it and it’s too mellow.  Price point is excellent but personally I’d spring for old overholt BIB if I was in the market for a rye as it’s far more spicy and interesting.
Every other sip I really pick up on the vanilla.  Spicy.  like it.

Color... Apple Juice gold, light sunny amber and less dark than others.

Nose... Rye all day long. If you know rye whisky then you'll pick up the 95 percent rye immediately. Sweet and leathery, tobacco like. Definite fruit though and alcohol burn.

Taste... The Tennessee smooth sipping style is apparent immediately. It matches the spiciness that the rye offers and mellows it perfectly, bringing about such sundae type flavors. 

Overall it's just so solid for the price and quality. At 20.00 USD it's an absolute steal, a must have in your collection of rye whisky and brown liquor in general.
Buttery and spicy with just enough rye. Enough burn afterwards. Good with southern BBQ pork chops, Memphis ribs or a good crayfish broil.
Herbal. Dill pickle. A bit gin like.

Bright spices, mixed with an underaged rye. Not a whole lot of barrel character, going for the grain instead. Accesses hints of spoke every other sip. Although the finish cleans up with the charcoal finish, it fades quite quickly.
Not overly harsh for a rye
From my memory this was excellent but as I don’t remember it well enough I shall need to try it again.
Outstanding rye at its price point. Great flavor and nose
First rye I’ve ever had. Spicy, dry and herbal. Was initially kind of “meh”, but the more I drink the the more I like it.
Spicy. Very sweet with a cherry finish.
Not great neat. Slightly better with ice. Get some Willett Family Estate

A smooth and easy sipper. Nose is light in spice with subtle hints of banana, brown sugar.  For $20 you can’t go wrong.   This is one of my favorite pours (neat) when I’m looking to be thrifty but don’t want to skimp on taste.
I love George Dickel whisky, but this isn't George Dickel whisky- it's MGP. Minty in a toothpaste sort of way and odd. It does grow on you, but it's an odd whisky.
This is a very good well balanced rye. Rye spiciness is distinct on both the nose and taste, with a hint of vanilla. Even though it is a Tennessee style rye, it has a good mouthfeel.
Surprisingly smooth for the low cost, warmth on initial taste, fading to a relatively sweet, peppery finish.

Peat?, dry frt., soft oak, dill, exc. bal , ling finish on palate
H20; peppermint, anise, dill, clove.
Soft & sweetish, spicy, full finish.

Wonderfully complex rye. Nothing particularly overpowering for the front, with a nice long peppercorn-y finish.  It's great at 90 proof, and the rye-bread and other spices really shine through after a few more sips.  A very nice rye for the price, surprised it doesn't have a bigger following.

Dill intensely up front in your face. Rosemary. Charred oak on the back burner. Hint of pepper and brown sugar. Once I take a sip, the dill aroma subsides a little. Malt and vanilla dominate the palate and it leaves a lingering coat of sugar on my tongue. I wouldn’t call this dry. Dill comes through even on the flavor. Mint comes in to finish the herb and spice parade. Too herbal for a sipper for me but overall great for the money
10/12/19 Beer Bourbon & BBQ fest in Leesburg

Nose: cherry, pine, bacon, mint
Taste: cherry cough syrup, mint but more of a fresh feeling than minty taste, leather, some baking spice - maybe clove
Finish: a little oakiness comes through beyond the notes in the taste but those do linger a while
After reading reviews: distiller references way more herbal notes than I got but I’ve had extreme herbal ryes like High West Double Rye and this isn’t like that, Flaviar noted cherry which was the dominant profile for me (along the lines of Old Forester Rye) as well as the mint that was featured prominently in Whizzky reviews.  Also some mentions of savory or smoky notes that align with the bacon I got on the nose.  This tasting was from the polishing off of a bottle I bought several years ago, so there could have been some oxidation.  Even still, this reminded me that it’s a damn fine whiskey and especially for the price.

Aroma is bright and sharp, even smells soapy or minty. Bright spicy flavor as well, there must be some flavor in there that's coming off as soap for me. Has a much richer finish and tail than I expected for the price.
A nice spicy rye with vanilla and herbaceous notes with a sweetish finish. This is my go to for Manhattans. Never had a complaint! A great value too. I always keep a bottle around.
It's good, but I taste pickles. And I hate pickles.
Spicy and rich. I always think this tastes a lot more expensive than it is. Great value!

Nose: Bold fresh herbs like rosemary. A little soapy. Some oaky astringency. A little bit of lemon.
⠀
Taste: Sweet vanilla and floral notes. A little oaky, a little herbacious. A bit astringent. Ultimately not getting much as much pungent herb flavor as when I first opened the bottle, but that's ok, it was a bit much.
Good spice without being too spicy. Good with an ice ball and in old fashions. A go to cheaper rye

Very iteresting, inexpensive rye. Eucalyptus, spearmint, an baking spice nose. Buttery, lightly sweet, and slightly spicy mouthfeel. Smooth, lightly spicy, short finish. Good/interesting, but not a flavor for mixing, and not great for sipping neat.
Another rye I bought as a mixer that surprised me.  This made a really good Manhattan and is great for the price.  A little spice from the rye but nice and smooth.
Definitely a favorite. Excellent quality for the money.
Another bottle too cheap to pass up. Not as good as Bulleit for me, but still better than average (and well worth the price).
Really like this in an Old Fashioned.

George Pickle rye smells just like a dill dickel! Wait, umm.. I mean... 

I do get a strong dill scent on the nose of this whiskey. There’s also a strong hint of freshly cut grass and some black pepper and other spices. 

I really hate pickles, and thankfully, this stuff tastes nothing like the little green devils. The flavor is fairly complex, and quite well-rounded for what it is. There’s no corn in the mashbill, but there’s still plenty of vanilla-y sweetness and tongue-coating creaminess. Quite lovely. 

This is the same MGP 95% rye mashbill as Angel’s Envy Rye and Bulleit Rye. I like this whiskey just as much as Bulleit, and it’s smoother to boot. It’s unfair to compare it to AE Rye, since AE is much older and rum-finished, but Dickel can hold its own ground. 

The value is superb, and the whiskey is enjoyable for both beginners and seasoned rye enthusiasts.
Whoa, that's a weird one! Smells like dill and pickles, but tastes a bit nutty, a bit spicy and, oh, so creamy. A lot to decipher here!
Still developing a taste for rye's but this was very spicy and tart i liked it.

Nose: eucalyptus, tea, mint
Taste: vanilla, citrus, light spice
Finish: medium, spicy, light dill oily finish
Rye. Spices. Cloves. Leather. Pepper. Vanilla.
Grassy nose, smooth sweet vanilla palette, spicy and sweet finish

It tastes like dill pickles. Weird. 
Edit: I've give a better review, but this stuff is still weird. It's a very floral rye, not deep or rich. Foral almost like a Bulleit rye.The charcoal mellowing process is one that I'd imagine to bring a rich wood and char flavor but it just mellows it out and makes it almost like a syrup (if that makes sense). The George Dickel Bourbon expresses that mellowness even more. Now for my comment on the dill pickles. A few other people notice this too but we are all unique so maybe you won't notice it but for me, it smells exactly like dill pickle juice. And I soon as I noticed it, I can't get rid of it. It's not for me but that's the awesome thing about whiskey, its unique to the drinker. Some people love it and thats awesome! But it's too mellow, floral, and pickley for me. Give me some Knobb creek rye over this.

I got my 750 ml bottle @ Walmart on closeout for $12.50, plus tax. This has a clear, amber appearance, standard fence board alcohol legs, and a sweet, savory, and minty spiced nose. The flavor is of spicy, sweet grain, charred oak, and even Aim toothpaste. Mouthfeel is medium, and George Dickel Rye finishes quick to moderate. RJT
Solid rye. Great spiciness from the rye.

Nose: mint, sweet (toffee? marshmallow?), eucalyptus, baking spices, dill, breathe deep to get isopropyl that turns to pine/resin

Taste: white peppercorn, dill, lemon peel, nutmeg, cardamom, vanilla,

When a buddy of mine who hates ryes told me that he was into this whiskey, I was surprised.  When I tasted the whiskey, I was even more surprised.  The Rye spice was barely noticeable, only coming out after the whiskey is long gone.  Dickel Rye does have an odd tongue numbing astringency with bigger drinks, so just stick to sips.  A rye whiskey for people who don't like rye whiskies.
Spicy, with ground pepper, some kind of dried herb, and a dry oak at the end. Finish is medium-long, with that herbal note hanging on.... maybe rosemary with slight dill?

Spicy, vanilla oak, some mint, classy, mellow. Hot alc but smooth.
Cloves, spice, soft & smooth finish.
Nice Rye. Smooth beginning with a distinct Rye taste. Slight rasp finish. Caramel and vanilla undertones decent rye and the price was less than $30.
